1.content:
Amber jumped in her seat. The bus driver wasn't taking care to avoid any potholes in the streets. Amber wished she didn't have to ride the bus, but since the accident, her car was still in the shop. It will take another three weeks before she could have it back, so in the mean time, public transportation was her only option.

*Sttsssss* Amber heard the familiar sound of the air brakes and the door swinging open. She got up from her seat and exited the bus at Jefferson and Kline St. A few other people, one woman with her daughter, a man wearing some very nasty sandals, and another man wearing a very worn our blue shirt. 'What else could I have done with my life,' Amber reflects. She could blame herself, it was her decision to move to to the city. She'd always wanted to escape the small town, to get a big paying job, and live the good life. The college told her that the world was looking for people with a degree in math; couldn't get enough of them. Now that she's got it, though, it seems that the world could certainly get by without her expertise in functions and formulas.

And taking that first step, she decided to get a second job. Her first job was working at John's Deli, and she liked working there, but she couldn't afford anything other than essentials. So Amber lifted the classifieds and perused her circled options. "I guess I'll try applying at..."

1. Radioway Electronics Superstore
2. Chemtech Applied Chemicals
3. 'Fun In The Sun' Swim Park
4. Anderson, Marcus and Luke Law Firm

11.content:
“Well, Amber, I’d have to say I like your resume. The college degree is good, but you don’t have any sales experience. Are you driven enough to sell electronics?” “Oh yes, Mr. Grams. I’ll sell whatever I can to whoever I can.” “Good. I’ll tell you, the base pay isn’t great, but the money is in commissions. You sell enough cell phones and warranties, and you won’t go hungry.” Mr. Grams smiled at Amber.

He didn’t know if she’d make it, but Reggie Grams liked giving people their shot. Customers needed their shot to purchase what they need, and young college graduates needed their shot to make it in the real world. He couldn’t say right away, but he knew he was going to give Amber that shot. “That’s all the questions I have for you today. You’ll get a phone call if we need anything more, alright?” Amber smiled back, “Ok, thanks a bunch. Have a nice day.” She walked out of the office and through the store. Amber had never been in a sales position, but how hard could it be? She’d just have to get to know the equipment, and be as courteous to the customers as she could be. Of course, that’s if she even got the job.

The smile on Amber’s face slowly faded. She hadn’t thought that she wouldn’t get it, but what were her chances? She’d never sold anything before in her life, except sandwiches. She hopped onto the next bus, taking her to John’s Deli. Her shift started in an hour, so she had some time before she had to begin work. The bus reached the street corner after John’s, and Amber stepped off the bus. She walked down the street and turned into the familiar deli. “Hey Amber, you’re early?” A man in his late 20’s waved to Amber from behind the counter. Chris was on and would be working with Amber for her shift. Chris had been working in John’s for as long as Amber had, and they had a pretty good friendship established. They could take orders, turn out meals, and ring people up faster than some three, or even four, person teams could. That’s why they always worked the evening shifts; fewer people coming in, and the owner could save money by having two experienced employees working.

Amber walked behind the counter and picked up her apron. “How’s everything, Chris?” Amber asked. Chris furrowed his brow and formed a very deep, thoughtful pose. “Well Amber, with the bad economy, pollution, and conflict going on, everything is pretty bad,” he throws his arms wide and with a bright expression, “but as for me, I’m pretty fantastic!” Amber chuckles at his remark. Chris could always make her smile. He was a really sweet guy, nice to the good customers, a dick when he needed to be, but always looking out for Amber.

A few hours into the shift and Amber receives a phone call. “Hello?” “Hey, Amber, it’s Grams.” “Hey, Mr. Grams. What I can do for you?” “Well, you can come in tomorrow to pick up your shirts, you got the job!” Amber’s face went blank, then a smile. Chris was concerned because Amber didn’t usually stop her sandwich making, even with a phone call. Chris asked, “Amber, are you alright?” Amber stared jumping up and down, ignoring the burning steak for the Philly cheese she was supposed to be preparing. “Well that’s great Amber, but we have orders to fill.” Amber settled down and returned focus, “Alright, when can I come in?” “Be here at noon. I can take you out to lunch, go over the paperwork and give you your uniform. Sound good?” “Sounds great, Mr. Grams. I’ll see you then.” Amber hung up the phone and returned to her cooking.

The next day, Amber showed up to Radioway Electronics. The store looked different, as though she wasn’t viewing it as a customer, but as a sales person. Mr. Grims emerges from the back with a briefcase, passing people in matching polo’s. “Hello Amber, congratulations on getting the job.” Mr. Grims shook Amber’s hand. “Shall we? If you don’t mind Italian, I know this great place just down the street.

After some very tasty fettuccine, Mr. Grims pulls out his briefcase. “Now, I’ve just got some standard paperwork for you to fill out, standard boilerplate. Here’s your I-9, and W-2…” He started handing her paperwork to fill out, “Oh, and there’s this one, it comes down from the higher ups. Mostly just covering their and my rear, promising you won’t steal anything or kill anyone.” Mr. Grams laughed as he handed Amber what seemed to be a book. It was almost a hundred pages, filled with words and legal phrases. “You just need to sign the back. Of course, I can’t let you take it with you, but you just need to sign the back copy, and I can turn it in today.” Amber is a little wary. She knew she shouldn’t sign anything if she didn’t know what it was, but the amount of paper in here, it seemed like they were hiding something. Amber looked at the stack and then at Mr. Grams. Biting her lip, Amber…

info.brief_description: Authentic "choose-your-own" adventure story for expansion/inflation fetishists.
info.description:
This is an attempt at a more authentic “choose-your-own adventure”. What do I mean by that?

Most fetish based adventures on this site are more selective of what happens, and not, what you do. So then, those stories support choosing the effect, then writing cause. This story will be choosing the cause, then finding the effect. Get it?

No? Ok, think back to the old CYOA’s we used to read. You could choose the room to enter, but you didn’t know what was in that room. You could decide to take the bus or stay in the hotel, but you didn’t know what would happen. That’s the style we’re going for in this story. The main character doesn’t know exactly what’s going to happen, and neither will you. You can suggest she put on the ring, but you don’t know what will happen to her.

So when adding, create situations such as: (go to the house, stay in the pool, rubs herself)
ie. Immediate actions.

Avoid creating situations such as: (C cup, 5 feet, even bigger)
ie. Size choices, or knowledge she wouldn’t have in the story.

A few other rules:
Good grammar.
Weighty additions. No one-liners, paragraph at least.
Any expansion/inflation allowed (breast, butt, body, belly, other body parts, giantess).
No vore, no gore, no scat, no waste stuff.
Popping allowed as a reset, remember, no gore.
Keep growth reasonable, nothing too big too fast.

Feel free to email me if you have questions or ideas to make this a better story.
